answers.answer: All hospitals have nutritionists that can talk to patients.  You didn't say how obese you mother is or if she has any other health problems. I gather that the doctor isn't as worried about you mother's weight as you are. People do gain as they age and that is a good thing.  Fat cells produce a number of their own hormones and may "take over" for the ovaries as they begin to stop hormone production.  Fat cells in the aged also give them a "food source" against illness, whereby that storage of fat may "feed" the body when she becomes very ill and can't eat for herself for a few days.  People usually begin gaining about one pound per year after the age of 40 to accomodate these mentioned functions. Gall baldder disease isn't uncommon in this age group no matter the weight of the woman, nor is acquiring diabetes, especially if it "runs" in the family.  Unless your mother is more than 30 pounds overweight, try relaxing the worry cells.  Check with the nutritionist and make sure her diet is a healthy one and don't worry so much about what the bath scales are saying.  Good luck

question: My mother is 62 years old and obese.  She was diagnosed with type 2 diabetes a few years ago and is now admitted to a local hospital with an inflamed gall bladder.  She is to receive IV antibiotics until surgery can be performed.  I do not believe that her physician is being frank with her regarding her eating habits and how it is affecting her health.  Is there someone in the hospital that can talk to her and make her understand that she is killing herself with food?
title: My mother is eating herself to death
